thread.title: Creatures you might not want to see in the wild (17 Photos)
thread.title_full: Creatures you might not want to see in the wild (17 Photos)

author: Chiver Submitted
title: Creatures you might not want to see in the wild (17 Photos)
text:
Okapi – One of the coolest looking animals on this list because it’s half zebra and antelope, but they are most related to the giraffe! There are only 30,000 in existence and they’re in the Congo. 12 
Lyrebird – Some birds are noisy and then there’s the lyrebird. It can imitate any sound because of their strong syrnix muscle. We don’t know how many exist, but they live in Australia. 13 
Axolotl – Not a fish, but actually a salamander that can regrow lost limbs and heal itself. Native to Mexico and is also called the “Mexican Walking Fish” 14 
Golden Tortoise Beetle – This color-changing bug goes from gold to red when it’s mad or mating. There’s not a lot of information on them besides that they are only in the Americas. 15 Wikimedia/Stefan Brending 
Irrawaddy Dolphin – They are more similar to killer whales than dolphins, but they can squirt water to help herd fish when they are hungry. This type of dolphin is super rare and can only be found in the Bay of Bengal and and Southeast Asia coast. Advertisement Advertisement 16 
Narwahl – They don’t just exist in Elf, they are real! Narwahls have a 50-year life span and a unicorn-like horn that can grow up to 10 feet. There are only 75,000 left and they primarily live in the waters around Russia, Greenland, and the Canadian Arctic. 17 
Turritopsis Dohrnii aka ‘The Immortal Jellyfish”– A very small jellyfish that can never die. When it reaches the end of its life cycle it folds in on itself and transforms back into its early stages before growing into an adult jellyfish again. Super weird sea creature that lives in the Mediterranean Sea. 
Thanks again for another great iCHIVE gallery. Submit your gallery to iCHIVE for a chance to have it featured on theCHIVE homepage, earn the “Great Scott” badge, as well as 3,000 Chive Points.
